newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: Korea's Hyundai plans $1.4 billion Scotland chip plant.
newsitem.headline: Korea's Hyundai plans $1.4 billion Scotland chip plant.

text.p: Hyundai Electronics, a unit of South Korea's sprawling Hyundai Group, said Tuesday it planned a $1.4 billion semiconductor plant in Scotland to tap European markets with a new generation of computer memory chips.
"The main purpose of the project is securing a production base in Europe in order to expand our market share in the region and overcome trade barriers," a Hyundai spokesman said.
The plant will begin commercial production of dynamic random access memory chips in December 1998 and generate about 1,000 jobs, he said.

Hyundai's plan comes on the heels of LG Group's 1.7 billion British pound ($1 billion) deal in July to make semiconducters and electronic goods in Wales -- the biggest single overseas investment in Europe from outside the European region.

"Main items will be 64- and 256-megabit DRAMS, whose demand in Europe is expected to rise sharply from late next year on," the spokesman said. The 64-megabit and faster 256-megabit chips are considered a new generation in semiconductor products.

Prices for widely used 16-megabit DRAM chips have slumped following a huge glut of supply, weighing heavily on South Korean electronics firms and forcing them to look further abroad for new investment opportunities, analysts said.
The move to produce faster memory chips is particularly important for the South Korean economy, whose exports have been hit hard by spiralling prices for the 16-megabit chips.

The Scotland plant would be Hyundai Electronics' first European investment. The group began construction in February on a $1.3 billion semiconductor plant in the United States that is due to be completed late next year.
Hyundai said it selected Dunfermline, about 15 miles north of Edinburgh, because of various favourable conditions which Britain offered.
